SEARCH
Package gw.api.heatmap

Class RangeColorMap

java.lang.Object
gw.api.heatmap.RangeColorMap
All Implemented Interfaces:
HeatMapColorMap
public class RangeColorMap extends Object implements HeatMapColorMap
A HeatMapColorMap that maps ranges of values to colors and supports scaling for the label for the color in the map legend. RangeColorMap(colors) maps a value of n to colors[n-1].

RangeColorMap(colors, 1000) maps 1..1000 to colors[0], 1001..2000 to colors[1] and so forth.

RangeColorMap(colors, 1000, 1000) provides the same color mapping, but the amounts in the labels are divided by 1000. For example, you might use this to display amounts such as 1000 as "1K" (you'll need to override formatAmount()).

    • getColorForValue

      public Color getColorForValue(int value)
      Maps per-pixel point values to colors for the map overlay. A count of n uses Color[n-1]. If n-1 is outside the array bounds, then the first or last elements are used. If n is invalid input: '<'= 0, the method returns null, indicating the value should be ignored.

      Note that the overlay image generation routines don't use this when the counts are all 0; set OverlayBackgroundColor instead to set the overlay background color.

      Override this routine to do a different color mapping. For example, if the map shows dollar amounts, override getWeight() to map dollar ranges to colors (such as $0-10,000 -> blue, ...).

      Specified by:
      getColorForValue in interface HeatMapColorMap
      Parameters:
      value - The weighted value of points associated with a pixel.
      Returns:
      The color corresponding to the value, which may be null, indicating not to draw anything

    • formatAmount

      public String formatAmount(int value)
      Formats a value to appear in the label. The value has already been divided by the scale factor. Override this method
      Parameters:
      value - the value (already divided by the scale factor)
      Returns:
      the formatted value
